Title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives

Abstract:

This interdisciplinary project, "The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives," delves into the complex relationships between modernity, health, and disease in 19th-century literature, science, and medicine. Drawing inspiration from Benjamin Ward Richardson's seminal work, Diseases of Modern Life (1876), this research initiative seeks to explore the intersection of physiological, psychological, and social factors that contributed to the emergence of diseases associated with modern life.

Through a holistic and integrative Victorian vision, this project will employ cross-disciplinary scholarship to track the circulation of ideas across literature, science, and medicine, and to examine the connections between various factors that influenced health and disease during this period. The focus areas of investigation will include diseases caused by worry and mental strain, lifestyle diseases, environmental pollution diseases, and diseases specific to certain professions, among others.

The project aims to offer new ways of contextualizing the problems of modernity, providing breakthroughs in the compartmentalization of psychiatric, environmental, and literary history. By exploring the historical roots of modern health concerns, this research will contribute to a deeper understanding of the complexities of human health and disease, and shed new light on the ongoing challenges of modern life. The expected outcomes of this project will be significant, advancing new ground in scholarship and informing fresh perspectives on the intricate relationships between modernity, health, and disease.
